did.unittitle: J. Walter Thompson Company. Iconographic collection 1848-2005 and undated
did.physloc: For current information on the location of these materials, please consult the Library's online catalog.
did.abstract: Founded in 1864, the J. Walter Thompson Company (JWT) is one of the oldest and largest enduring advertising agencies in the United States.

The Iconographic Collection spans the years 1848-2005 with the bulk of materials dating between 1940 and 1985, and includes black-and-white and color photographs, negatives, slides, contact sheets, photograph albums, and microfiche. It is an artificial collection created to document the facilities, key events, advertising highlights and corporate culture of the J. Walter Thompson Company (JWT). Domestic and international offices are included, with the New York, Chicago and London offices being the most heavily represented. Key executives include James Walter Thompson, Stanley and Helen Landsdowne Resor, Don Johnston, Dan Seymour, Norm Strouse, and E.G. Wilson. Client advertising includes Ford, Kodak, Chesebrough-Pond's, Lever Brothers (Unilever), and Warner-Lambert. Notable photographers whose work appears in the collection include Fabian Bachrach, Ralph Bartholomew, Cecil Beaton, Louise Dahl-Wolfe, Philippe Halsman, Horst P. Horst, George Hurrell, Yousuf Karsh, Baron Adolf de Meyer, Bill Ray, Jean Raeburn, Edward Steichen, Thomas Veres, Brett Weston and Dorothy Wilding. Acquired as part of the John W. Hartman Center for Sales, Advertising & Marketing History.

accessrestrict.head: Access Restrictions
accessrestrict.p: However, nitrate negatives and some other items may not be accessible due to preservation concerns.
Additionally, reproduction-quality copies of Pond's Advertising Photographs may not be produced for non-JWT users.
Researchers must register and agree to copyright and privacy laws before using this collection.
All or portions of this collection may be housed off-site in Duke University's Library Service Center. The library may require up to 48 hours to retrieve these materials for research use.
Please contact Research Services staff before visiting the David M. Rubenstein Rare Book & Manuscript Library to use this collection.

userestrict.head: Copyright Notice
userestrict.p: The copyright interests in this collection have not been transferred to Duke University. For more information, consult the copyright section of the Regulations and Procedures of the David M. Rubenstein Rare Book & Manuscript Library.

scopecontent.head: Collection Overview
scopecontent.p: The Iconographic Collection spans the years 1848-2005 with the bulk of materials dating between 1940 and 1985, and includes black-and-white and color photographs, negatives, slides, contact sheets, photograph albums, and microfiche. It is an artificial collection created to document the facilities, key events, advertising highlights and corporate culture of the J. Walter Thompson Company (JWT). Domestic and international offices are included, with the New York, Chicago and London offices being the most heavily represented. Key executives include James Walter Thompson, Stanley and Helen Landsdowne Resor, Don Johnston, Dan Seymour, Norm Strouse, and E.G. Wilson. Client advertising includes Ford, Kodak, Chesebrough-Pond's, Lever Brothers (Unilever), and Warner-Lambert. Notable photographers whose work appears in the collection include Fabian Bachrach, Ralph Bartholomew, Cecil Beaton, Louise Dahl-Wolfe, Philippe Halsman, Horst P. Horst, George Hurrell, Yousuf Karsh, Baron Adolf de Meyer, Bill Ray, Jean Raeburn, Edward Steichen, Thomas Veres, Brett Weston and Dorothy Wilding.

arrangement.head: Collection Arrangement
arrangement.p: Collection is arranged into eight series: Corporate Events; Office Photographs; Officers and Staff Photographs; Negatives; Pond's Photographs and Negatives; Slides; Thomas Veres Photographs and Negatives; and Oversize Materials.

Corporate Events includes photographs of some of JWT's art and artifact collections as well as of meetings, seminars and anniversary parties of company-wide significance. Office Photographs document interiors and exteriors of JWT's domestic and international office buildings. Officers and Staff Photographs primarily feature senior-level management, but there are also publicity photographs and group portraits of departments, sports teams, and employee outings. Negatives comprise negatives associated with the Corporate Events, Office Photographs, and Officers and Staff Photographs Series. Pond's Photographs and Negatives include portraits of celebrities and socialites taken by leading photographers for Pond's beauty products advertising campaigns. Slides consist primarily of monthly advertising highlights as well as materials assembled for presentations. Thomas Veres Photographs and Negatives consist of work performed by Veres under contract to JWT, primarily of company events and staff. Oversize Materials include large-format materials pulled from other series.

scopecontent.p: Restrictions on Access: Reproduction-quality copies of Pond's Advertising Photographs may not be produced for non-JWT users.

scopecontent.p: Consists of photographs of official meetings and events that have corporate-wide significance: management meetings; major training seminars; anniversaries and retirement parties of key executives; and corporate mergers. Also includes limited photographs of art items owned by JWT, and of historical artifacts held by the JWT Archives.

Arranged into Artifacts and Publications; Corporate Artwork; Meetings; Programs; Seminars; Corporate Expansion; and Recognition Events. Order reflects original order of series as received from JWT Archives. Corresponding negatives have been moved to the Negatives Series and noted in the container list.

scopecontent.p: Contains photographs of exteriors and interiors of buildings housing JWT offices around the world; office activities such as employee events, outings, and celebrations; and client related activities. Organized into U.S. and International categories. The U.S. offices are organized with New York first, followed by Chicago and then the rest of the U.S. offices listed alphabetically. International offices are organized alphabetically by country and city. Corresponding negatives have been moved to the Negatives Series and noted in the container list.

[Includes photographs of all the buildings the office has occupied: 244 Madison Avenue (1918); 41 Park Row; East 23rd Street; the Graybar Building (420 Lexington Avenue); 466 Lexington Avenue. Also includes photographs of Charles Sheeler-designed Colonial/New England dining room (1923); Samuel Yellin's iron grillwork (circa 1920s).]

scopecontent.p: The bulk of photographs are of the London office, but other offices are depicted. Many of the photographs were collected in the 1960s by Connie Ivie, then Manager of International Services. Most offices sent her photographs of interiors and exteriors of buildings, some depicting staff at work. Arranged alphabetically by country and city.

scopecontent.p: Photographs of JWT staff, primarily senior officers. There are substantial sets of photographs of J. Walter Thompson; Stanley and Helen Resor; Sam Meek; Norman Strouse; Dan Seymour; and Don Johnston. For many officers, there are both formal and candid poses, although many photographs were taken for publicity purposes. Notable photographers include Edward Steichen (Helen Landsdowne Resor, 1925; Stanley Resor, 1930; and perhaps John Reber, circa 1930); Brett Weston (James Webb Young, circa 1950); Jean Raeburn; Fabian Bachrach; Yousseff Karsh; and Bill Ray (Don Johnston, 1984). Arranged alphabetically by name. Corresponding negatives have been moved to the Negatives Series and noted in the container list.

scopecontent.p: Includes images primarily of celebrities and noted socialites, taken for a long-running campaign for Chesebrough-Pond's beauty products. Arranged into two categories: Photographs and Negatives. Photographs reside in numbered folders. Negatives are sorted by format and arranged according to the corresponding folder number; loose negatives are arranged alphabetically by name.
Restrictions on Access: Reproduction-quality copies of Pond's Advertising Photographs may not be produced for non-JWT users.

scopecontent.p: The bulk of slides in this series comprise images taken of materials existing elsewhere in the JWT Archives and used as the basis for presentations made by the Archives staff as well as by other departments within the agency. Later additions to the slide collection include portraits and snapshots added and interfiled over time.

The series is organized into five self-evident categories: Clients; Offices; People; Miscellaneous Slides; and Microfiche. Clients and Offices are both organized into Domestic and International, and therein alphabetically: Clients by name; and Offices by country and city. People are organized alphabetically by name. Miscellaneous slides include group snapshots; logos and publications (primarily images of covers and title pages); and intact slide shows. Microfiche primarily contains images of client print advertisements, along with house advertisements for competitive agencies, and some new business presentations.

did.unittitle: Best of the Month/ What's New (1-361, 362-428, 1-97), undated

scopecontent.p: [In 1971 the JWT New York Office began selecting advertisements as Best of the Month for display in exhibit areas of each floor of the company office. Creative Group heads chose 1-8 advertisements from all proofs of a given month, including those from: the New York Office; Brouillard Communications; Deltakos; and Entertainment Group. The basis for selection was the best blending of art and copy. Beginning in 1980, slides of television commercial storyboards were included. The program continued until 1981. In this collection the slides are numbered 1-428 and appear in roughly chronological order. There were two cross-reference lists at the JWT Archives, one chronological by number, with campaign information available for many of the slides; and one arranged alphabetically by client. See Research Services for access to these files. (From original JWT Archives description.)]

Thomas Veres Photographs and Negatives, 1963-1996 and undated

scopecontent.p: Thomas Veres was a New York photographer under contract to JWT beginning in 1963. He photographed corporate events, staff, and other items. Many of his photographs were used to illustrate newsletter articles. Materials are segregated into Administrative Files (mainly paper records), Photographs and Negatives. Photographs and Negatives are organized according to Veres' job code, a three-part number identifying the quarter, year and job number. For example, a code 1-2-69 indicates job number 2 of the first quarter of 1969. Photographs taken prior to 1969 were received without job numbers and have been organized by year and therein alphabetically by subject.

Bartholomew, Ralph Jr., images for Kodak, 1947-1952

scopecontent.p: [Ralph Bartholomew, Jr., began his career in advertising as an Assistant Art Director at Batten, Barton, Durstine & Osborn (BBDO). Upon leaving BBDO, he returned to art school and after graduating went to work at the Detroit branch of a large New York studio. In the early 1940s Bartholomew returned to New York to open his own studio in Manhattan, and in 1946 began accepting photographic assignments from JWT. M. Katherine Wiggins, the Art Consultant at JWT, introduced Bartholomew and his work to Fenton Powers, the Art Director on the Kodak account.]

[Powers assigned Bartholomew to work on campaigns for a variety of products. In 1948 Kodak recognized the need to reach the burgeoning adolescent market with its camera and film products. Among Bartholomew's first assignments were photographs for these teen-directed campaigns. Powers and Thayer Jaccaci, the Kodak Account Executive, chose Bartholomew's photographs for much of the teen-directed advertisements over the next eight years.]

[In taking the photographs of teenagers, Bartholomew used non-professionals as models, as he preferred their unaffected reactions. Many of the young people were recruited from the public high school in Scarsdale, the town where Bartholomew lived. Settings for the photographs were ones that were familiar to the inexperienced models: the Danbury Fair, Jones Beach, and Scarsdale itself.]

[This collection of prints date from 1947 to 1952, and originally consisted of 20 tear sheets and proofs; 24 photographs; and one issue of Commercial Camera. The tear sheets and proofs were primarily employed in the teen-directed campaigns. The 24 photographs, consisting of 23 black-and-white prints and one color print, were also used for Kodak advertisements directed toward teenagers. The issue of Commercial Camera (Vol. 1 No. 1, Oct./Nov. 1947) contained an article by Bartholomew, Not Just Because It's Fast. (From original description by Annamarie V. Sandecki, JWT Archives, 1980.)]
